div.head: Title
div.p: Untitled in draft. When a revised version was published in the literary annual, Friendshipʼs Offering (see Composition and Publication), the poem first exhibited its title, “Saltzburg”; however, this title must have been determined by that of the steel engraving, which the poem was commissioned to accompany.

div.head: Genre
div.p: Ekphrastic and topographical poem.

div.head: Manuscripts
div.p: Draft contained in MS VIII (see Contents, list b.2).

div.head: Date
div.p: Composed probably between May and July 1834, in time for submission deadline in August.

div.head: Composition & Publication
div.p: Published in Friendshipʼs Offering; and Winterʼs Wreath . . . for MDCCCXXXV, 317–19). “Saltzburg” is an ekphrastic poem, paired with the plate Saltzburg, engraved by Edward Goodall (1795–1870) after a drawing by William Purser (ca. 1790–1852).

“Saltzburg” is one of two contributions comprising Ruskinʼs debut in Friendshipʼs Offering, the other contribution being two travelogue poems collected under the title “Fragments from a Metrical Journal”. The latter represents the first published outcome of Ruskinʼs ambitious illustrated verse and prose travelogue, Account of a Tour on the Continent), while “Saltzburg” can be viewed as an independent creative project arising from skills and insights that he developed in the “Account” from studying the illustrated travel literature of his time.

A draft of “Saltzburg” is contained in MS VIII, where it forms the terminus ad quem for draft connected with the “Account”. For discussion of the positioning and date of this draft in MS VIII, see Account of a Tour on the Continent: Date of Composition—Abandonment of the Project; and for discussion of the development from draft to published version, see Hanson, “Ruskin in the 1830s”, 143–47.

div.head: The Circumstances of the Commission
div.p: Elsewhere, Hanson has argued that W. G. Collingwood was misled by an assumption that Ruskin would have composed a topographical poem only about a place he had actually seen, and that therefore Ruskinʼs commission for “Saltzburg” must have been associated with his familyʼs visit to Salzburg during their Continental tour of 1835. This alleged timing of the commission would have been impossible, however, given that the poem must have been submitted for publication one year earlier than this journey, in order to be included in Friendshipʼs Offering . . . for MDCCCXXXV, released for the winter holiday season of 1834–35 (see Hanson, “Ruskin in the 1830s”, 122).

More significantly, Collingwoodʼs underlying assumption was faulty, as well, since Ruskinʼs poem preceded his aesthetic of “truth to nature” by a decade. The poem was composed in response, not to nature, but to the print culture of illustrated travel writing of the 1830s. Ruskin, like many other contributors to the literary annuals, had no personal experience of the place that his persona pretended to traverse; instead, his informaton about the place was drawn from printed sources, while his creative response was primarily ekphrastic, an engagement with the engraving of the foreign scene (Hanson, “Ruskin in the 1830s”, 143–47).

While Collingwood was certainly wrong about the winter 1835 date of this commission--not only had Friendshipʼs Offering . . . for MDCCCXXXV already been published, but Pringle had been dead for a year--Collingwoodʼs speculation about the circumstances of the assignment bear inquiry. He assumes a casual happenstance, under pressure of a deadline: “It happened that Mr. Pringle had a plate of Salzburg which he wanted to print in order to make up the volume of Friendshipʼs Offering for the next Christmas” (Life and Work of John Ruskin, 1:52). It is credible that Pringleʼs regard for the Ruskin family and his genuine appreciation of Ruskinʼs abilities prompted him to solicit, for the same volume of Friendshipʼs Offering containing “Saltzburg”, Ruskinʼs “Fragments from a Metrical Journal”, a work extracted and revised from the “Account” of the Tour of 1833 (see Account of a Tour on the Continent: Publication—Friendshipʼs Offering). It seems an extraordinary undertaking, however, to have appointed a fifteen‐year‐old first‐time contributor to compose the text for an embellishment produced especially for the annual by an artist well-established with the annual and an important engraver, and Collingwood's explanation does not hold up: Ruskin's assignment of “Saltzburg” was not a rush job, the probable April-May 1834 date of its draft, along with its many differences from the publsihed version, indicating ample time for revision; and his neophyte status was unusual, Pringle having previously appointed only experienced hands to supply letterpress for landscape plates.

div.head: Strategies for Ekphrasis
div.p:
In Friendship's Offering under Pringle's editorship, the prose tales paired with landscape plates work in a description of the scene, typically at a climactic point, and the plate is tipped in close to that page in the text. For a tale of thirteenth-century Venice, Charles Macfarlane (1799-1858) is forced into an awkward accounting of Samuel Prout's modern scene, St. Mark's Place, Venice (engraved by E. J. Roberts [1797-1865]), but one that resonates with Ruskin's later strategies in Stones of Venice, by referring to structures in the plate that were not present in the setting of the story, when "Venice . . . was not yet the splendid city that . . . could . . . boast that accumulation of ancient and modern art, which was afterwards to attract the stranger from many a distant land"; rather, "at the epoch of our tale, Venice was about equi-distant from what she was at her humble origin,--a collection of low huts scattered on the sea-lashed sand, banks and rocks . . . and what she became became after the sixteenth century, when the wealth of the East had been poured in her lap, and the genius of Palladio and others had filled her with beauty" (Friendshipʼs Offering . . . for MDCCCXXXI, 196-98)

That Pringle gave preference, when possible, to writers with personal experience of the places they described (as Collingwood took for granted was the case in Ruskin's assignment to Purser's would have shown his regard for the Ruskin family, and formalized his role of mentor and friend to the young poet, just as Rogers had condescended to Pringle.

div.head: Pringleʼs Mentorship
div.p: It can be added to this argument that, in assigning this commission to the young writer, Pringle replicated an ekphrastic assignment he had given to himself four or five years earlier, as editor of Friendshipʼs Offering . . . for MDCCCXXX. That volume also featured an engraving after William Purser, the artist of Saltzburg. Entitled Spoleto and engraved by Thomas Jeavons (1795–1867), the plate may have been the first work by Purser to appear in the annual. Pringle gave himself the task of writing the accompanying text, although he had never visited the Continent, much less Spoleto, which was not well known to English travelers. In the 1820s, Mariana Starke devoted only a brief paragraph to the town, in the course of describing the route from Rome to Florence. In the 1830s, William Brockedon drew more attention to the town, highlighting the picturesque views to be discovered in the approach and surrounding countryside (Starke, Travels in Europe between the Years 1824 and 1828 [1828], 411; Brockedon, Travellerʼs Guide to Italy [1835], 144; Brockedon, Road‐Book from London to Naples, illus. Stanfield, Prout, and Brockedon [1835], 130). Even Purser probably lacked first‐hand experience of the scene, having based his drawing, according to the engravingʼs caption, on “a sketch by Captain [Robert] Melville Grindlay”, who had connections with Smith, Elder (see Chatterjee, Robert Melville; and see Smith, Elder & Company for its connections with the East India Company).

In the plate, Purser renders the scene on a plan similar to the composition of Saltzburg. Spoleto is viewed from a distant, central vantage in the countryside above the town, with the town>ʼs major monuments picked out in the middle ground. In the foreground, figures in local costume orient the spectatorʼs gaze toward the prospect. Pringleʼs accompanying text, “Spoleto”, makes no pretence of traveling farther than from the armchair. Consisting of a prose preface and a poem, the piece fills the page facing the engraving with an extract from a travel account, A Classical Tour through Italy (1813) by the Reverend John Chetwode Eustace (1761–1815), which summarizes the triumph of ancient defenders of Spoleto against invasion by Hannibalʼs army, and which highlights major monuments of the town today.

Pringle swerves from this dry annotation, however, to introduce what “will probably be esteemed by most readers [as] more interesting than pages of further details from more ordinary tourists”—some observations on Spoleto from an unpublished travel journal lent by Samuel Rogers (1763–1855). Although much briefer and less informative than the extract from Eustaceʼs published account, Rogersʼs jottings are in keeping with the governing sentiments of the literary annuals—friendship and memory. “[B]y his kind indulgence”, the “author of the ‘The Pleasures of Memory’” has shared his reminiscences of Spoleto. The quotation is a curtailed and revised version of a passage that would later be included in The Italian Journal of Samuel Rogers:

Spoleto, with its walls and turrets, soon appeared on the mountain side. . . . The gate of Hannibal [i.e., Porta Fuga]. . . . The gigantic aqueduct crossing a deep and unfathomable chasm [i.e., Ponte delle Torri]. . . . Saw it by moonlight; and its vastness and entireness, connecting us at once with some mighty and unknown people, affected me deeply.
(Friendshipʼs Offering; A Literary Album . . . for MDCCCXXX, 109; and see The Italian Journal of Samuel Rogers, ed. Hale, 205)

Pringle abridged the original passage (or perhaps Rogers did so, when presenting it to Pringle), presumably in order to heighten the closing poetic sentence—an evocation of the scene by moonlight, with a meditation on history. In the poem that follows these prose extracts, after an ekphrastic description of the scene for which Eustaceʼs account is serviceable, it is Rogers“s sentiment that frames the speakerʼs reflections, as he positions himself in the classic pose of a figure in a prospect poem:

lg.l: Spoleto! midst thy hills and storied piles,
Thy classic haunts and legendary aisles,
ʼTwere sweet, methinks, ere life hath passed away,
To spend one long, reflective summerʼs day;
Beneath those quiet shades my limbs to cast,
And muse oʼer all that links thee to the past;
To linger on, through twilightʼs wizard hour,
Till the wan moon gleamed high oʼer rock and tower,
And, with her necromantic lustre strange,
Lit up the landscape with a solemn change—
Gilding its grandeur into sad relief,
Like a pale widow stately in her grief.

div.p: The pose and meditation are conventional, but the additional frame of Rogersʼs shared reflections adds the theme of friendship, rendering this ekphrastic travel piece peculiarly appropriate to the literary annual. Friendship is brought forward explicitly in the conclusion of the poem, as Pringle pays tribute to one “Whom ʼtis a pride and grace to call my Friend”. At the same time, the poet/speaker qualifies this friendship as unequal, as he subordinates himself to Rogersʼs fame. The speaker self‐consciously acknowledges that his meditation on the prospect is indebted to the scene that, as described in the journal, once “rose . . . on Rogersʼ classic eye”; and he pays deference to the elder poetʼs greater capacity to encompass such a view, for “[h]ad he to verse transferred it [the scene] from his mind”, the “touching image” would have been “enshrined” and “embalmed in words that could ne“er die”. Word and image may be joined equally as Sister Arts in the literary annual, but not poets. Whereas Rogersʼs poetry was destined to be “embalmed”, “Far other fate awaits this rustic lay, / Framed for the passing purpose of a day”. While the scrap from Rogersʼs journal carries the literary annualʼs stock themes of memory and fellow‐feeling, Friendshipʼs Offering nonetheless maintains the neoclassical ordering of the arts, bringing Pringleʼs own “Spoleto” comfortably down to what he considers its proper level for an ephemeral publication (Friendshipʼs Offering; A Literary Album . . . for MDCCCXXX, 111).

In this deferential tribute to Rogers and its implication of Pringle's humble conception of the annual's place in literary and artistic culture, we perhaps can glimpse Pringle's expectations when arranging to usher his prodigy into Rogers's presence at the poet's famous St. James Place residence--an event as extraordinary as awarding a (practically) unpublished fifteen-year-old a commission as prominent as the composition to accompany a featured embellishment by a highly respected engraver. No account of this episode has survived apart from Ruskin's dismissive treatments of it, written decades later for "My First Editor" and Praeterita (Hanson, Ruskin in the 1830s 000; Samuel Rogers), In "My First Editor", written in memory of Pringle's successor as editor of Friendship's Offering, W. H. Harrison, Ruskin presents Pringle's demeanor as a "grave authority" in contrast to Harrison's "ready praise" and "cheerful auspices"--Pringle's mentorship admitting only "doubtfully, but with benignant sympathy, . . . the dazzling hope that one day rhymes of mine might be seen in real print, on those amiable and shining pages". The characterization of amiability and friendship is tied to the annual itself, while a hierarchical rigidity is associated with Pringle and his "cross-examination" of Ruskin in Rogers's presence, resulting in a rebuke of the boy for "not attending" to the conversation between his elders, which was over his head (Works, 34:96-97). The characterization is consistent with the unequal friendship between poets represented in Spoleto, while overlooking the humility that actuated Pringle's estimation of himself and his publication.

of a tribute to an elder and greater poet occupies the entirety of Pringleʼs conclusion of his poem on Spoleto, framing the ekphrasis as chose Ruskin in spite of the youthʼs lack of professional experience, in part because the editor was impressed by the youthʼs ability to match words with pictures, but also because behind the scene he could dedicate the assignment as an act of friendship. Four years later, when Pringle had another plate by Purser, Saltzburg, to assign to a writer for the upcoming volume for 1835, he chose Ruskin in spite of the youth's lack of professional experience, in part because the editor was impressed by the youth's ability to match words with pictures, but also because behind the scene he could dedicate the assignment as an act of friendship. Since it was at about this time that Pringle arranged for Ruskin to be introduced to Samuel Rogers, and escorted him to Rogers's St. James Place residence (Hanson, Ruskin in the 1830s, 000; Samuel Rogers), it is more probable that Pringle would have invested the "Saltzburg" commission with greater significance than the mere happenstance that W. G. Collingwood supposes--that "[i]t happened that Mr. Pringle had a plate of Salzburg which he wanted to print in order to make up the volume of Friendship's Offering for the next Christmas" (Life and Work of John Ruskin, 1:52). Rather, in conferring such an impressive commission on a fifteen-year-old first-time contributor, Pringle would have shown his regard for the Ruskin family, and formalized his role of mentor and friend to the young poet, just as Rogers had condescended to Pringle. A tribute to an elder and greater poet occupies the entirety of Pringle's conclusion of his poem on Spoleto, framing the ekphrasis as an offering to a lasting poet from the pages of an ephemeral publication, "Framed for the passing purpose of a day" in the calendar of an annual, by a "rustic" Scots poet:

About four years later, when Pringle had another plate by Purser, Saltzburg, to assign for the upcoming volume for 1835, one can only speculate whether, in bestowing that significant opportunity on a (practically) unpublished fifteen-year old, he imagined himself replicating the patronage by the senior man of letters that. If so, did Pringle cast Ruskin as the lesser talent, or merely less experienced? The one certainty is that Pringle premised his bid for the reader's friendship on his humility. The conclusion to “Spoleto”, consists of an offering to a lasting poet from the pages of an ephemeral publication, “Framed for the passing purpose of a day” in the calendar of an annual, by a “rustic” Scots poet:
Lines from Pringle's "Spoleto" are possibly echoed by Ruskin in "Saltzburg".

The extract first highlights the town's fame for repulsing an attack by Hannibal's army, following the Cathaginian victory over Rome, a continuing source of local pride which is mentioned in all guidebooks. The passage then scans the town's major monuments, using a strategy that may have been instructive to Ruskin. As a Roman Catholic priest, Eustace dwells on the Gothic cathedral, of course admiring its beauty in contrast with lighting its lurid fascination as Ruskin does; however, the passage also presents views of the cathedral that are invisible in the plate, such as details from its interior, and the prospect looking outward from its terrace. This accidental juxtaposition of conflicting viewpoints may have given; the "barbarous antiquity" of its castle (see Eustace, A Classical Tour through Italy, 1:177-79).
Forsyth 3d ed, 1824, 2:94; Lalande 6:247-50
